snippet: While Syria met an important deadline, it still has 1,290 metric tons of chemical weapons it must destroy by mid-2014, inspectors said.
abstract: Weapons inspectors say that Syria's ability to produce chemical weapons has been destroyed and its remaining toxic armaments secured, although almost 1,300 metric tons of weapons remain; elimination of Pres Bashar al-Assad's manufacturing ability is significant milestone, offering sign of his robust cooperation with Russian-United States accord and allowing his government to seize new measure of credibility.

byline.contributor: Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London, and Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva.

lead_paragraph: While Syria met an important deadline, it still has 1,290 metric tons of chemical weapons it must destroy by mid-2014, inspectors said.

headline.main: Syria Destroys Chemical Sites, Inspectors Say
headline.print_headline: Syria Destroys Chemical Sites, Inspectors Say
